commands.name: Step 1: Create Namespace
commands.command: kubectl create namespace scenarios --dry-run=client -o yaml | kubectl apply -f -
commands.explanation: Creates namespace for rolling update demonstration.

commands.name: Step 2: Deploy v1
commands.description: Deploy nginx deployment and service with nginx:1.20-alpine (version 1)
commands.explanation: Creates deployment with 3 replicas and service running nginx:1.20-alpine. Uses RollingUpdate strategy with maxSurge:1 (can create 1 extra pod) and maxUnavailable:1 (at most 1 unavailable during update).
commands.next_step: Verify v1 is running before updating.

commands.name: Step 3: Verify v1 Running
commands.command: kubectl get pods -n scenarios -l app=rolling-demo -o jsonpath='{.items[*].spec.containers[*].image}' | tr ' ' '\n' | sort -u
commands.description: Check that all pods are running nginx:1.20-alpine
commands.explanation: Extracts container images from all pods and shows unique values. All should be nginx:1.20-alpine (v1).
commands.what_it_does: Lists unique container images currently running.
commands.next_step: All pods on v1. Now update to v2.

commands.name: Step 4: Update to v2
commands.command: kubectl set image deployment/rolling-demo app=nginx:1.21-alpine -n scenarios
commands.explanation: Triggers a rolling update. Kubernetes gradually replaces v1 pods with v2 pods. With maxUnavailable:1, at most 1 pod is down at a time, ensuring service availability.
commands.what_it_does: Updates deployment image, starting the rolling update to v2.
commands.next_step: Watch the update progress in real-time.

commands.name: Step 5: Watch Rolling Update
commands.explanation: Shows real-time progress: 'Waiting for deployment rollout to finish: 2 out of 3 new replicas have been updated...' then 'deployment rolled out'. Takes 30-90 seconds as pods update sequentially.
commands.what_it_does: Streams rolling update status until successfully completed.
commands.next_step: Update complete! Verify all pods are on v2.

commands.name: Step 6: Verify v2 Running
commands.command: kubectl get pods -n scenarios -l app=rolling-demo -o jsonpath='{.items[*].spec.containers[*].image}' | tr ' ' '\n' | sort -u
commands.description: Confirm all pods updated to nginx:1.21-alpine
commands.explanation: Should now show only nginx:1.21-alpine (v2). The rolling update completed with zero downtime - service was available throughout.
commands.what_it_does: Lists unique container images after update.
commands.next_step: Check deployment history to see revisions.

commands.name: Step 7: View Rollout History
commands.explanation: Shows all revisions: Revision 1 (nginx:1.20), Revision 2 (nginx:1.21). Kubernetes keeps last 10 revisions by default (configurable with revisionHistoryLimit). This enables rollback capability.
commands.what_it_does: Lists all deployment revisions with change causes.

commands.name: Step 8: Rollback to v1
commands.explanation: Reverts to Revision 1 (nginx:1.20). Rollback is another rolling update - same strategy, just backwards. Takes 30-90 seconds with zero downtime.
commands.what_it_does: Performs rolling update back to previous revision.

commands.name: Step 9: Verify Rollback
commands.command: kubectl get pods -n scenarios -l app=rolling-demo -o jsonpath='{.items[*].spec.containers[*].image}' | tr ' ' '\n' | sort -u
commands.description: Confirm pods are back on nginx:1.20-alpine
commands.explanation: Should show nginx:1.20-alpine again. Rollback successful! Both forward updates and rollbacks maintain zero downtime.
commands.what_it_does: Verifies current container images after rollback.
commands.next_step: Scenario complete! You've mastered rolling updates.

commands.name: Cleanup: Delete Resources
commands.explanation: Deletes all resources created in this scenario.
